The two in parenthesis does mean there are two items: the tsuba and the the tsuba box bearing a hakogaki by Torigoye.  

The 4560 pounds + 20 % buyer's premium of 912 = 5472 x 1.752 conversion rate to dollars = 8760 more or less, but probably a little more.   But it is a famous piece, one we all recognize from the book. 

DZ


----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Ron Hartmann 
  To: TOKEN ; nihonto@yahoogroups.com ; nihontostudy 
  Sent: Saturday, July 16, 2005 9:16 AM
  Subject: Sotheby auction


  Hi all - 

  Not having the catalogue for Alan Harvie's tsuba (Sotheby's auction just ended), I'm curious if lot 706 was a single tsuba or was that for multiple tsuba. It appears to be a single, ex-Compton Kamakura-bori tsuba but further down (on the internet listing) it mentions "quantity 2" which puzzles me. Pretty healthy price for a tsuba, if indeed one tsuba. If so, would you say "provenance" played a big roll in achieving this price?

  Ron
  STL
